title: Unlimited PTO Guilt Tax
context: Companies replace fixed vacation policies with 'unlimited PTO' — take as much time as you need. It sounds generous. In practice, employees take less vacation, not more. Without a defined entitlement, there's no anchor. Nobody wants to be the person who takes 'too much.' Managers don't model healthy usage. The company saves money on accrued vacation liability while employees burn out faster.
hypothesis: Unlimited PTO gives employees more flexibility and leads to better work-life balance.

effects.label: Employees take fewer vacation days, not more

children.label: No anchor — employees don't know what's 'acceptable'
Social pressure and guilt prevent time off requests
High performers take the least time off — they feel most indispensable
No payout required when employees leave
Employees realize the policy benefits the company, not them
Trust erodes when employees see the financial incentive
Employees work through illness and personal needs
Guilt about taking time off creates chronic stress
Managers who don't take PTO set implicit expectations

effects.label: Inequity emerges across teams and demographics

children.label: Manager personality determines actual PTO culture per team
Junior employees and minorities take less time off due to visibility concerns

dontIf: Your company culture already has workaholic tendencies
Your managers don't model healthy time-off behavior
ifYouMust: Set a minimum required PTO (e.g., 'take at least 15 days') — make it a floor, not a ceiling
Require managers to take and visibly communicate their own PTO
Track and publish anonymized PTO usage data by team to surface inequities
Auto-schedule company-wide shutdown weeks to normalize time off

alternatives.name: Generous fixed PTO
alternatives.note: 25-30 days with mandatory minimums — clear entitlement removes guilt

alternatives.name: Minimum + flexible
alternatives.note: 15 mandatory days plus flexible additional days — anchors healthy behavior

alternatives.name: Company shutdown weeks
alternatives.note: 2-3 weeks per year where the entire company closes — eliminates individual guilt
